contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox City Japan |Name= Date |JapaneseName= 伊達市 |MapImage= Date in Fukushima Prefecture.png |Region= [[Tōhoku region|Tōhoku]] |Prefecture= [[Fukushima Prefecture|Fukushima]] |District= |Area_km2= 265.10 |PopDate= October 1, 2008 |Population= 65,409 |Density_km2= auto |Coords= |LatitudeDegrees= 37 |LatitudeMinutes= 49 |LatitudeSeconds= |LongtitudeDegrees= 140 |LongtitudeMinutes= 30 |LongtitudeSeconds= |Tree= |Flower= |Bird= |SymbolImage= |SymbolDescription= |Mayor= |CityHallPostalCode= 960-0692 |CityHallAddress= 180 Hobaramachi aza Funabashi, Date-shi, Fukushima-ken |CityHallPhone= 024-575-2570 |CityHallLink= [http://www.city.date.fukushima.jp/ City of Date] }} {{nihongo|'''Date'''|伊達市|Date-shi}} is a [[cities of Japan|city]] located in northern [[Fukushima Prefecture|Fukushima]], [[Japan]]. As of May 2011, the city has an estimated [[population]] of 65,409<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pref.fukushima.jp/toukei/html/01/m-jinko/22_23_3_4doutai.xls|publisher=Official Fukushima Prefecture website|title=Estimated population May 1, 2011|accessdate=29 July 2011}}{{ja icon}}</ref> and the total area is 265 km². There were nine towns in [[Date District, Fukushima|Date District]], [[Fukushima Prefecture|Fukushima]]. On January 1, 2006, five towns in Date District merged to form the city of Date. Merged towns were [[Hobara, Fukushima|Hobara]], [[Yanagawa, Fukushima|Yanagawa]], Date, [[Ryōzen, Fukushima|Ryōzen]], and [[Tsukidate, Fukushima|Tsukidate]]. The central town is [[Hobara, Fukushima|Hobara]]. A whole body skeleton of [[Paleoparadoxia]] was excavated in Yanagawa on August 21, 1984. The skeleton is named the Yanagawa Specimen. ==History of two Date Cities== In the [[Edo period]], the [[Date clan]] ruled the whole [[Miyagi Prefecture|Miyagi]] and the South of [[Iwate Prefecture|Iwate]]. The Date clan was one of the most influential [[daimyo]]s, samurai. In the [[Meiji period]], many samurai lost their territories because of the [[Meiji Restoration]]. This was also true for the Date clan. A party led by [[Watari, Miyagi|Watari]]-Date, a branch family of the Date clan, settled in uncultivated Hokkaido. This is the origin of Date in Hokkaido. On the other hand, the name of Date clan originated from the name of Date District in Fukushima. The Date clan rose in Date District in 12th Century. Date in Fukushima is the ancestral ground of Date clan. Date in Hokkaido is the ground of a descendant of Date clan. The two cities have an indirect relation. The Date family, descendants of [[Fujiwara no Uona]] (721-783) received the Date District in 1189 from the Shôgun [[Minamoto no Yoritomo]]. Before the Edo period, the home castle of Date clan was Yanagawa castle in Yanagawa in Date District. In the Edo period, the home castle was Sendai castle in [[Sendai]], Miyagi. == Economy == [[Taiyo Yuden]] operates a [[CD]] and [[DVD]] production plant in the [[Yanagawa Industrial Zone]] in Date, Fukushima. ==2011 earthquake and tsunami== Date is about {{convert|60|km|miles|abbr=off}} north-west of [[Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant]], the site of the [[Fukushima I nuclear accidents|nuclear accident]] that followed the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]]. Although outside the nuclear accident exclusion zone, the levels of radiation in the city caused residents, and especially schoolchildren, to remain indoors more.<ref name=reuters-20110331>{{Cite news |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-05-11/fukushima-students-wear-masks-as-radiation-looms.html |title=Fukushima Students Wear Masks as Radiation Looms |author=Takahiko Hyuga and Shigeru Sato |publisher=Bloomberg |date=11 May 2011 |accessdate=11 May 2011}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.city.date.fukushima.jp/ Date official website] {{ja icon}} {{Fukushima}} [[Category:Cities in Fukushima Prefecture]] {{Fukushima-geo-stub}}
